channel.title: Desserts on Gourmand Syndrome
channel.description: Recent content in Desserts on Gourmand Syndrome

item.title: Lysée
item.description: Dessert bars are not a new thing in NYC, but finding a very good one can be difficult. This one comes from Chef Eunji Lee, who comes from renowned Jungsik. My partner did see the chef in the kitchen when we were there. We were able to make a reservation for this several weeks in advance surprisingly without any hassle. When you walk in, there is a floor level section and an upper level section.

item.title: Patisserie Fouet
item.description: Summary Patisserie Fouet is another one of those Japanese French style dessert places where they also have a prix fixe (3 desserts). The yuzu jelly was ok. It is not like the panna cotta pictures on Yelp. It tasted like one of those raindrops that had some yuzu flavors in it. I didn’t care too much for it. The yuzu sugar sugar came with yuzu mousse, green tea sponge cake, Japanese yam, and black sesame ice cream.

item.title: Carlo's Bakery
item.description: Summary This place is known for the dessert chef featured on Cake Boss. To be quite honest, I’ve never watched it, so I don’t know what to expect. We got chocolate cannoli, plain cannoli, some red velvet cake thing, and lobster tail. To be honest, the lobster tail was actually quite good and was my favorite of everything. The lobster tail’s pastry thin crust was flaky but not brittle. It tasted like a delicate thin but sturdy crust of a pastel I had at Aldea.

item.title: Dō Cookie Dough
item.description: Summary The cookie dough here is pretty sweet. Tried multiple flavors, but all of them are all pretty sweet. I also used some of the batter and baked some cookies. They turned out ok, though no different than if you to were make regular cookies. One scoop by the way makes about 5 ok sized cookies. Honestly, I thought the one of the better things to get was not the dough itself, but the ice cream sandwich.

item.title: Lady M Cake Boutique
item.description: This was in a small mall, and it was pretty good. We got the eclairs and apple flan.

item.title: Baked by Melissa
item.description: These are super tiny one bite mini cupcakes. Pretty good though the flavor profiles aren’t that different from each other.

item.title: Grom
item.description: I like the gelato here. A bit expensive but good.

item.title: Grace Street
item.description: Desserts are pretty good, but I don’t get why there is always a line here. The milk tea was just ok. The donuts were good.

item.title: Dominique Ansel Kitchen
item.description: Interesting desserts and pretty good. In the summer, they have burrata frozen yogurt as well as some type of watermelon frosty thing. They’re also known for the Cronut, but it can be bought at the Spring location.

item.title: Patisserie Chanson Dessert Bar
item.description: Amazingly good albeit super expensive for a dessert tasting menu. Six courses plus wine pairing for $150+. Geez.

item.title: Soft Swerve
item.description: Pretty good matcha soft serve ($5).

item.title: Daly Pie
item.description: Got the rhubarb, and it was pretty good. I love them rhubarb pies.

item.title: Ample Hills Creamery
item.description: Got the pistachio brittle, and it was mediocre. I think Van Leeuwen is better.

item.title: ChaTime
item.description: Passion fruit green tea was just OK.

item.title: Kulu Desserts
item.description: It’s ok. Lots of durian stuff. Black sesame wasn’t that great.

item.title: Creperie
item.description: Really good and BIG.

item.title: Spot Dessert Bar
item.description: Pretty good. Some interesting stuff, but maybe somewhat gimmicky?

item.title: Kreuther Chocolate
item.description: Across from Bryant Park. Expensive AF chocolate ($3 pp), but the other desserts were amazing. Really good chocolate though.

item.title: Viva La Crepe
item.description: Crepes were whatever. Why?

item.title: Prince Tea House
item.description: Good crepes and milk tea. The decor is interesting here. The iced passionfruit green tea was a nice drink for the hot summer weather. The takoyaki was pretty good.

item.title: Maison Kayser
item.description: The Christmas log is good. A lot of Frenchy desserts.

item.title: Cafe Zaiya
item.description: Decent black sesame bubble milk tea with red bean dessert bakery stuff.

item.title: Patisserie Tomoko
item.description: They have dessert tasting menus. The black sesame is good. The black sesame ice cream is amazing. Not too sweet, but also very punchy in flavor. Delicious. The green tea roll was very good. The center was cold and creamy, but not too sweet. The pumpkin tart was really good too. The crust was flaky similar to an egg tart.

item.title: Rice to Riches
item.description: This will be my last NY food post for a while. For the last day to cap off the trip, we went to Rice To Riches in Nolita. This was actually really close to our Blue Ribbon meal a few posts ago. Rice To Riches is basically the equivalent to Baskin Robbins 31 flavors in LA. Instead of many choices of ice cream, you have many choices for tapioca. You also have the option of sampling any flavor that you want.

item.title: Chikalicious
item.description: Per recommendations for dessert after dinner at Momofuku Ko, we visited Chikalicious. All I know is this place is busy normally with lines outside the door. My buddy and I visited it on a Thursday night, and to our surprise it wasn’t overly busy at all. In fact we got there right at 9:30 PM. There were 2 seats at the counter right in front of the Chef Chika. Yes, Chika is her name.
